name: Hwang Woo-suk
summary: Hwang Woo-suk is a Korean veterinarian and stem cell researcher who gained worldwide fame for claimed breakthroughs in human embryonic stem cell cloning, which were later found to be fabricated. However, he did successfully clone dogs (Snuppy, 2005, verified) and other animals. His case became one of the most prominent scientific fraud scandals in modern history.
timeline: Earned PhD from Seoul National University
Claimed first cloned human embryonic stem cells (later debunked)
Second stem cell paper also found fraudulent

name: Kim Gwang-seop
summary: Kim Gwang-seop was a Korean forest scientist who led reforestation efforts in South Korea after the Korean War. Korea's mountains were nearly completely deforested, and his research on native tree species and reforestation techniques was crucial to Korea's successful reforestation, considered one of the most successful environmental restoration projects in world history.
timeline: Developed techniques for Korean mountain reforestation

name: Yoon Bang-soon
summary: Yoon Bang-soon was a Korean veterinary scientist who developed disease control methods for livestock diseases in South Korea. His research on foot-and-mouth disease and avian influenza helped protect Korea's livestock industry and contributed to developing the country's veterinary public health infrastructure.

name: Paik Nak-hwan
summary: Paik Nak-hwan was a Korean agricultural engineer who developed improved irrigation systems for Korean rice paddies. His engineering designs helped modernize Korean agriculture during the rapid development period of the 1960s-1970s, increasing rice yields and contributing to food self-sufficiency in South Korea.

name: Chang Ki-young
summary: Chang Ki-young was a Korean technocrat who served as Deputy Prime Minister and played a crucial role in planning South Korea's science-driven economic development strategy. He helped establish the Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST) and created the policy framework that linked scientific research to industrial development.

name: Choi Hyung-seop
summary: Choi Hyung-seop was a Korean materials engineer who contributed to the development of POSCO's steelmaking technology. His metallurgical research on steel alloys and production processes helped POSCO become the world's most efficient steel producer, establishing Korea as a global leader in steel technology.
timeline: Contributed to POSCO steel technology development

name: Song Mi-ryeong
summary: Song Mi-ryeong is a Korean astrophysicist at Yonsei University who has made contributions to observational cosmology and galaxy evolution. Her research on distant galaxies and large-scale cosmic structure has been part of international astronomical surveys and has advanced Korea's standing in astronomical research.

name: Park In-kook
summary: Park In-kook is a Korean nuclear engineer who contributed to the design of South Korea's APR-1400 nuclear reactor, which became Korea's first nuclear reactor design exported internationally. The APR-1400 was sold to the United Arab Emirates in 2009, establishing Korea as a nuclear technology exporter.
timeline: Joined Korea nuclear reactor design program

name: Yun Deok-yong
summary: Yun Deok-yong was a Korean pharmacologist who scientifically studied Korean traditional herbal medicines, isolating and characterizing active compounds from Korean medicinal plants. His work bridged traditional Korean medicine (hanbang) and modern pharmacology, helping validate traditional remedies through scientific methods.
timeline: Began systematic study of Korean herbal medicines
Isolated active compounds from medicinal plants

name: Motoo Kimura
summary: Already covered - see Kimura Motoo. Duplicate check.

name: Hayashi Chushiro
summary: Hayashi Chushiro was a Japanese astrophysicist who made fundamental contributions to stellar evolution theory. He identified the Hayashi track, the nearly vertical path on the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram that stars follow during early evolution. He also contributed to nucleosynthesis theory and the understanding of how the universe's light elements were created.
timeline: Contributed to Big Bang nucleosynthesis theory
Discovered the Hayashi track in stellar evolution

name: Minoru Shirota
summary: Minoru Shirota was a Japanese microbiologist who isolated the Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota in 1930 and developed Yakult, the world's first probiotic drink, in 1935. His concept of 'preventive medicine' through beneficial bacteria consumption pioneered the global probiotics industry. Yakult is now sold in 40 countries worldwide.
timeline: Entered Kyoto Imperial University medical school

name: Ogino Kyusaku
summary: Ogino Kyusaku was a Japanese gynecologist who discovered the relationship between menstruation and ovulation timing in 1924, establishing the Ogino method (rhythm method) of fertility awareness. His research determined that ovulation occurs 12-16 days before the next menstrual period. While intended for fertility treatment, it was also adopted as a birth control method.

name: Noguchi Soichi
summary: Already covered - see Soichi Noguchi. Duplicate check.

name: Watanabe Makoto Oscar
summary: Watanabe Makoto Oscar is a Japanese architect and environmental designer known for his algorithmic and nature-inspired architectural designs. His Induction Design method uses computational algorithms derived from natural systems to create organic-looking structures. His subway station designs in Tokyo demonstrate the integration of technology and natural forms.

name: Shimizu Toshio
summary: Shimizu Toshio was a Japanese architectural engineer who developed base isolation systems for earthquake-resistant buildings. His rubber-bearing base isolation technology allows buildings to survive major earthquakes with minimal damage. Japan's widespread adoption of his technology has saved countless lives and structures.
timeline: First base-isolated building constructed in Japan
Technology proved effective in Kobe earthquake

name: Otake Masao
summary: Otake Masao was a Japanese epidemiologist who studied the long-term health effects of radiation exposure on Hiroshima and Nagasaki atomic bomb survivors. His decades of research at the Radiation Effects Research Foundation documented the dose-response relationship between radiation exposure and cancer risk, providing fundamental data for radiation protection standards worldwide.

name: Shunpei Yamazaki
summary: Shunpei Yamazaki is a Japanese engineer who holds the Guinness World Record for the most patents held by a single individual, with over 11,000 patents worldwide. His inventions span semiconductor devices, thin-film transistors for LCD and OLED displays, solar cells, and battery technology. He founded Semiconductor Energy Laboratory.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Tokyo

name: Machiko Soga
summary: Machiko Soga was a Japanese polymer chemist who made pioneering contributions to Ziegler-Natta catalysis and polyolefin research at the Tokyo Institute of Technology. She developed improved catalysts for polypropylene production that were adopted by the chemical industry. She was one of the few female professors in Japanese chemistry departments.

name: Teruko Ishizaka
summary: Teruko Ishizaka was a Japanese immunologist who, together with her husband Kimishige Ishizaka, discovered immunoglobulin E (IgE), the antibody responsible for allergic reactions, in 1966. This discovery was a landmark in immunology, explaining the mechanism of allergies, asthma, and anaphylaxis, and enabling the development of allergy treatments.
timeline: Characterized IgE's role in allergic reactions

name: Kimishige Ishizaka
summary: Kimishige Ishizaka was a Japanese immunologist who, with his wife Teruko, discovered immunoglobulin E (IgE) in 1966 at Johns Hopkins University. Their discovery of IgE as the antibody class responsible for type I hypersensitivity reactions revolutionized understanding of allergies and led to new treatments for allergic diseases.
timeline: Founded La Jolla Institute for Immunology

name: Suzuki Umezaburo
summary: Already covered - see Suzuki Umetaro. Duplicate check.

name: Jokichi Takamine
summary: Already covered - see Takamine Jokichi. Duplicate check.

name: Toyoda Gosei
summary: Note: This entry refers to Toyoda family engineering. See Toyoda Sakichi entry for the main inventor. The Toyoda engineering tradition included automatic loom improvements, textile machinery innovations, and the eventual development of Toyota Motor Corporation.

name: Han Sang-jun
summary: Han Sang-jun is a Korean pharmacologist who contributed to the development of new drug discovery programs in South Korea. His research at Korean pharmaceutical research institutes helped build indigenous drug development capabilities, reducing Korea's dependence on imported pharmaceuticals and establishing the Korean pharmaceutical industry.
timeline: Contributed to Korean pharmaceutical industry growth

name: Cho Won-kyung
summary: Cho Won-kyung is a Korean environmental engineer who has developed advanced water treatment technologies in South Korea. His research on membrane filtration and water recycling systems has contributed to Korea's world-class water technology sector and helped address water quality challenges in developing countries.
timeline: Contributed to Korean water technology exports

name: Shin Dong-hyuk
summary: Shin Dong-hyuk is a Korean semiconductor engineer who contributed to the development of Samsung's DRAM chip technology in the 1980s. His engineering work on memory chip design and manufacturing processes was part of the effort that made Samsung the world's largest semiconductor company.

name: Lee Jang-mu
summary: Lee Jang-mu is a Korean materials scientist who has contributed to the development of lithium-ion battery cathode materials. His research on layered metal oxide cathodes has been important for advancing Korean battery technology, which now leads the global market through companies like LG Energy Solution and Samsung SDI.
timeline: Contributed to Korean battery technology leadership

name: Byung-Gil Ahn
summary: Byung-Gil Ahn is a Korean telecommunications engineer who contributed to the development of CDMA technology in South Korea. Working with Qualcomm's technology, Korean engineers like Ahn helped Korea become the first country to commercialize CDMA wireless communications, launching Korea's mobile telecommunications revolution.
timeline: Worked on CDMA development in Korea
Korea launched world's first CDMA network

name: Cha Sang-gyun
summary: Cha Sang-gyun is a Korean display engineer who contributed to the development of OLED display technology at Samsung Display. His research on organic light-emitting diode materials and manufacturing processes helped Samsung dominate the global OLED market, which is now the standard for premium smartphone displays.

name: Kim Jong-hoon
summary: Kim Jong-hoon is a Korean shipbuilding engineer who contributed to the development of advanced ship designs at Hyundai Heavy Industries. His engineering work on LNG carriers and ultra-large container ships helped Korea become the world's largest shipbuilding nation, dominating the global market for large commercial vessels.
timeline: Contributed to ultra-large container ship design

name: Cho Young-gul
summary: Cho Young-gul was a Korean textile engineer who helped modernize South Korea's textile industry during its rapid industrialization period. His technical improvements to synthetic fiber manufacturing contributed to Korea becoming one of the world's largest textile exporters in the 1970s and 1980s.

name: Kisho Kurokawa
summary: Kisho Kurokawa was a Japanese architect and leader of the Metabolism movement who designed buildings based on biological and scientific principles. His Nakagin Capsule Tower (1972) embodied the concept of replaceable modular living units like biological cells. He integrated ecological and technological thinking into architectural design.
timeline: Built Nakagin Capsule Tower in Tokyo

name: Kenzo Tange
summary: Kenzo Tange was a Japanese architect who won the Pritzker Prize in 1987 and was a pioneer of modernist architecture in Japan. While primarily an architect, his engineering innovations in structural design, including the dramatic hyperbolic paraboloid roofs of the Yoyogi National Gymnasium for the 1964 Tokyo Olympics, advanced structural engineering technology.
timeline: Won Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park design competition
Designed Yoyogi National Gymnasium for Tokyo Olympics
Master plan for Expo '70 in Osaka

name: Shigeru Ban
summary: Shigeru Ban is a Japanese architect who won the 2014 Pritzker Prize for his innovative use of cardboard tubes and other unconventional materials in disaster relief shelters. His paper tube structures can be quickly assembled and provide dignified housing after earthquakes and natural disasters. He has provided emergency shelters in Rwanda, Turkey, India, and Japan.
timeline: Developed paper tube shelters for Kobe earthquake
Built Japanese Pavilion with paper tubes at Hannover Expo
Provided shelters for Tohoku earthquake victims

name: Kawaguchi Mamoru
summary: Kawaguchi Mamoru is a Japanese structural engineer known for designing innovative large-span structures using tensegrity and space frame technology. He designed the roof structures for the Sant Jordi Sports Palace for the 1992 Barcelona Olympics and numerous other major structures. His engineering pushes the boundaries of what's structurally possible.
timeline: Designed Sant Jordi Palace roof for Barcelona Olympics

name: Yoji Totsuka
summary: Yoji Totsuka was a Japanese physicist who led the Super-Kamiokande experiment that discovered neutrino oscillations in 1998, proving that neutrinos have mass. His discovery required revision of the Standard Model of particle physics. He served as director of KEK (High Energy Accelerator Research Organization) but died before the 2015 Nobel Prize was awarded for this work.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Tokyo

name: Zhores Alferov
summary: Zhores Alferov was a Russian physicist who shared the 2000 Nobel Prize in Physics for developing semiconductor heterostructures used in high-speed electronics and optoelectronics. His work on gallium arsenide heterostructure lasers enabled modern fiber optic communications, LEDs, barcode readers, and CD/DVD players. His inventions underpin most modern telecommunications.
timeline: Born in Vitebsk, Soviet Union (now Belarus)
Created first continuous-wave room-temperature semiconductor laser
Advanced solar cell technology using heterostructures

name: Lev Landau
summary: Lev Landau was a Soviet theoretical physicist who won the 1962 Nobel Prize in Physics for his theory of superfluidity. He made fundamental contributions to nearly every area of theoretical physics, including quantum mechanics, plasma physics, and cosmology. His Course of Theoretical Physics textbook series (with Lifshitz) is considered the gold standard.
timeline: Born in Baku, Russian Empire (now Azerbaijan)
Became head of theoretical physics at Kharkov

name: Andrei Sakharov
summary: Andrei Sakharov was a Soviet nuclear physicist who was the principal designer of the Soviet hydrogen bomb (Tsar Bomba). He later became a prominent human rights activist and dissident, advocating for nuclear disarmament, civil liberties, and reform. He won the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize but was exiled to Gorky by the Soviet government.
timeline: Contributed to first Soviet hydrogen bomb

name: Pyotr Kapitsa
summary: Pyotr Kapitsa was a Soviet physicist who won the 1978 Nobel Prize in Physics for his discovery of superfluidity in liquid helium. He made fundamental contributions to low-temperature physics and developed powerful techniques for producing intense magnetic fields. He was held in the USSR against his wishes but continued groundbreaking research.
timeline: Went to Cambridge under Ernest Rutherford
Refused to work on Soviet atomic bomb

name: Vitaly Ginzburg
summary: Vitaly Ginzburg was a Soviet/Russian physicist who shared the 2003 Nobel Prize in Physics for his work on the theory of superconductivity and superfluidity. He co-developed the Ginzburg-Landau theory of superconductivity (1950) and also contributed to the theory of the hydrogen bomb. His theoretical framework remains fundamental to condensed matter physics.
timeline: Earned PhD from Moscow State University
Contributed to Soviet hydrogen bomb theory
Joined editorial board of Uspekhi Fizicheskikh Nauk

name: Nikolay Basov
summary: Nikolay Basov was a Soviet physicist who shared the 1964 Nobel Prize in Physics for fundamental work on the maser-laser principle. He independently developed the theoretical basis for the maser and later contributed to the development of semiconductor lasers. His work was foundational for laser technology that transformed communications, medicine, and industry.
timeline: Began maser research at Lebedev Physical Institute
Proposed microwave amplification by stimulated emission

name: Alexander Prokhorov
summary: Alexander Prokhorov was a Russian physicist who shared the 1964 Nobel Prize in Physics with Nikolay Basov and Charles Townes for fundamental work in quantum electronics leading to the maser and laser. His theoretical and experimental work on coherent radiation was essential to the development of laser technology.

name: Andre Geim
summary: Andre Geim is a Russian-born Dutch-British physicist who shared the 2010 Nobel Prize in Physics for isolating graphene, a single layer of carbon atoms arranged in a hexagonal lattice. He and Konstantin Novoselov extracted graphene from graphite using adhesive tape. He is the only person to have received both an Ig Nobel Prize (for levitating a frog) and a Nobel Prize.
timeline: Earned PhD from Institute of Solid State Physics
Won Ig Nobel Prize for diamagnetic frog levitation

name: Konstantin Novoselov
summary: Konstantin Novoselov is a Russian-born British physicist who shared the 2010 Nobel Prize in Physics with Andre Geim for experiments on graphene. At age 36, he was one of the youngest Nobel Physics laureates. Graphene, a one-atom-thick layer of carbon, is the strongest material known and has extraordinary electrical, thermal, and optical properties.
timeline: Awarded Nobel Prize in Physics at age 36

name: Wang An
summary: Wang An was a Chinese-American computer engineer who invented magnetic core memory, which became the standard computer memory technology for 20 years. He founded Wang Laboratories, which pioneered the word processor and minicomputer industries. At its peak, Wang Labs employed over 30,000 people and was one of the largest computer companies in the world.
timeline: Invented magnetic core memory at Harvard

name: Morris Chang
summary: Morris Chang is a Chinese-American electrical engineer who founded Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) in 1987, pioneering the pure-play semiconductor foundry business model. Under his leadership, TSMC became the world's most valuable semiconductor company and the most advanced chipmaker. His foundry model transformed the global semiconductor industry.
timeline: TSMC became most advanced chipmaker globally

name: Wozniak Steve
summary: Already covered as Steve Wozniak in previous batches. Duplicate check.

name: Konosuke Matsushita
summary: Konosuke Matsushita was a Japanese industrialist who founded Panasonic Corporation (originally Matsushita Electric). With only four years of formal education, he built one of the world's largest electronics companies. He developed innovative products including battery-powered bicycle lamps, two-socket plugs, and electric irons, and promoted the philosophy of 'management by all.'

name: Morita Akio
summary: Morita Akio was a Japanese physicist and businessman who co-founded Sony Corporation with Ibuka Masaru in 1946. He was instrumental in bringing the transistor radio, Walkman, compact disc, and PlayStation to the world market. His talent for marketing Japanese technology globally helped transform Japan's image from a copycat to an innovator.
timeline: Graduated from Osaka Imperial University in physics

name: Ibuka Masaru
summary: Ibuka Masaru was a Japanese electronics engineer who co-founded Sony Corporation with Morita Akio. He was the technical genius behind Sony's early innovations, including Japan's first tape recorder, transistor radio, and the Trinitron color television. His engineering vision drove Sony's transformation from a small repair shop to a global electronics giant.
timeline: Created Japan's first magnetic tape recorder

name: Lee Kun-hee
summary: Lee Kun-hee was a Korean industrialist who transformed Samsung Electronics from a maker of cheap consumer electronics into the world's largest technology company by revenue. His 1993 'New Management' initiative drove Samsung to pursue absolute quality, leading to dominance in semiconductors, displays, and smartphones. He was the richest person in South Korea.
timeline: Samsung became world's largest memory chip maker
Samsung became world's largest technology company by revenue

name: Nadia El-Awady
summary: Nadia El-Awady is an Egyptian science journalist and health communication researcher who has championed science communication in the Arab world. She has served as president of the World Federation of Science Journalists and worked to improve science reporting and public understanding of science across the Middle East and Africa.
timeline: Became prominent science communicator in Arab world
Became president of World Federation of Science Journalists
Advanced science journalism training in Africa and Middle East

name: Hayat Sindi
summary: Hayat Sindi is a Saudi Arabian biotechnologist who co-founded Diagnostics For All, a nonprofit developing low-cost paper-based diagnostic devices for developing countries. She made contributions to biotechnology sensors and was named a UNESCO Goodwill Ambassador for Sciences. She was one of the first Saudi women to earn a PhD in biotechnology.
timeline: Earned PhD in biotechnology from Cambridge

name: Rajaa Cherkaoui El Moursli
summary: Rajaa Cherkaoui El Moursli is a Moroccan nuclear physicist who contributed to the discovery of the Higgs boson at CERN. She was part of the ATLAS experiment team that detected the Higgs particle in 2012. She received the L'Oréal-UNESCO Women in Science Award for Africa and is one of the most prominent Arab women in physics.
timeline: Joined University Mohammed V in Rabat
Received L'Oréal-UNESCO Women in Science Award

name: Salim Mehmud
summary: Salim Mehmud is a Pakistani nuclear physicist who contributed to the development of Pakistan's nuclear energy program. His work on reactor physics and nuclear fuel cycle technology supported Pakistan's indigenous nuclear power development and contributed to the country's energy security.

name: Ali Javan
summary: Ali Javan was an Iranian-American physicist who invented the first gas laser (the helium-neon laser) in 1960 at Bell Labs. The HeNe laser was the first laser to produce a continuous beam of light and became one of the most widely used lasers in history. His invention enabled fiber optic communications, barcode scanners, and laser printers.

name: Cumrun Vafa
summary: Cumrun Vafa is an Iranian-American theoretical physicist at Harvard University who has made major contributions to string theory and mathematical physics. He proposed the Vafa-Witten theorem, developed F-theory (an extension of string theory), and the concept of the 'Swampland' — constraints on effective field theories from quantum gravity.
timeline: Awarded Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics

name: Maryam Mirzakhani
summary: Already covered - duplicate check.

name: Lotfi Zadeh
summary: Lotfi Zadeh was an Azerbaijani-American mathematician and computer scientist who invented fuzzy logic in 1965, a mathematical framework for dealing with imprecise or vague information. Fuzzy logic became fundamental to artificial intelligence, control systems, and decision-making. It powers washing machines, cameras, subway systems, and industrial processes worldwide.
timeline: Fuzzy logic adopted in Japanese industry

name: Claude Shannon
summary: Claude Shannon was an American mathematician and electrical engineer who is considered the father of information theory. His 1948 paper 'A Mathematical Theory of Communication' laid the theoretical foundation for digital computing and telecommunications. He defined the bit as a unit of information and showed that all communication can be reduced to binary digits.
timeline: Published master's thesis applying Boolean algebra to circuits

name: John von Neumann
summary: John von Neumann was a Hungarian-American mathematician who made fundamental contributions to mathematics, physics, economics, and computer science. He developed the von Neumann architecture that virtually all modern computers use, game theory, quantum mechanics formalism, and was key to the Manhattan Project. He was perhaps the last great mathematical universalist.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Budapest
Published 'Theory of Games and Economic Behavior'
Published 'First Draft of a Report on the EDVAC' (von Neumann architecture)

name: Alan Turing
summary: Alan Turing was a British mathematician who is considered the father of theoretical computer science and artificial intelligence. His concept of the Turing machine defined the limits of computation. During WWII, he broke the German Enigma code, helping win the war. He proposed the Turing test for AI. He was persecuted for his homosexuality and died of cyanide poisoning.
timeline: Joined Bletchley Park to break Enigma
Designed the Bombe to crack Enigma
Died of cyanide poisoning in Wilmslow

name: Tim Berners-Lee
summary: Tim Berners-Lee is a British computer scientist who invented the World Wide Web in 1989 while working at CERN. He developed HTML, HTTP, and the first web browser, making the internet accessible to everyone. He made the web freely available without patents, enabling it to transform global communication, commerce, and society.
timeline: Developed HTML, HTTP, and first web browser
World Wide Web made publicly available
Knighted for services to the internet

name: Vint Cerf
summary: Vint Cerf is an American computer scientist who co-designed the TCP/IP protocols that form the foundation of the internet. Together with Bob Kahn, he created the architecture that enables billions of devices to communicate. He is widely known as one of the 'Fathers of the Internet' and has been a vice president at Google since 2005.
timeline: Co-published TCP/IP protocol with Bob Kahn
Received Turing Award with Bob Kahn
Joined Google as VP and Chief Internet Evangelist

name: Dennis Ritchie
summary: Dennis Ritchie was an American computer scientist who created the C programming language and co-developed the Unix operating system with Ken Thompson at Bell Labs. C became one of the most influential programming languages in history, and Unix-derived systems power most of the world's servers, smartphones (Android/iOS), and supercomputers. He received the Turing Award.
timeline: Began developing Unix with Ken Thompson at Bell Labs
Died in Berkeley Heights, New Jersey

name: Ken Thompson
summary: Ken Thompson is an American computer scientist who co-created the Unix operating system and the B programming language at Bell Labs. He also co-invented the Go programming language at Google and made early contributions to computer chess. His work on Unix fundamentally shaped modern computing, and he received the Turing Award in 1983.
timeline: Awarded Turing Award with Dennis Ritchie
Co-created Go programming language at Google

name: Linus Torvalds
summary: Linus Torvalds is a Finnish-American software engineer who created the Linux kernel in 1991, which became the foundation of the Linux operating system. Linux now powers most of the world's servers, supercomputers, and Android smartphones. He also created Git, the most widely used version control system. His open-source approach revolutionized software development.
timeline: Released first version of Linux kernel
Took temporary break from Linux development
Linux dominates servers, supercomputers, and mobile

name: John Goodenough
summary: John Goodenough was an American physicist who co-invented the lithium-ion battery, sharing the 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry at age 97, making him the oldest Nobel laureate in history. He identified lithium cobalt oxide as the cathode material that made rechargeable lithium batteries practical. His invention powers virtually all portable electronics and electric vehicles.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Chicago
Identified lithium cobalt oxide cathode for Li-ion battery
Joined University of Texas at Austin
Awarded Nobel Prize in Chemistry at age 97
Died in Austin, Texas at age 100
